title: 103_hr4541
content:
The Organization of African Unity is authorized to receive funds to strengthen its conflict resolution capability, including sending experts in conflict resolution. A minimum of $1,500,000 for each fiscal year from 1995 to 1998 should be allocated for this purpose from foreign assistance funds designated for sub-Saharan Africa. Additionally, there is a provision to improve conflict resolution capabilities of multilateral subregional organizations in Africa. The President is authorized to provide assistance to strengthen conflict resolution capabilities of subregional organizations in sub-Saharan Africa by allocating funds for supporting their conflict resolution capability and sending experts in conflict resolution. Foreign assistance funds for sub-Saharan Africa can be used for this purpose from 1995 to 1998. SEC. 5. AFRICAN DEMOBILIZATION AND RETRAINING PROGRAM.

The President is authorized to provide assistance for the demobilization and reintegration of military personnel in sub-Saharan Africa by allocating $25,000,000 for each of the fiscal years 1995 and 1996 from foreign assistance funds. This includes activities such as encampment, retraining for civilian occupations, income-generating opportunities, reintegration into agricultural activities, and transportation to their home areas. SEC. 6 amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to establish a program for conflict resolution and peacekeeping training in sub-Saharan Africa. SEC. 7 focuses on building mediation capability in Africa. SEC. 7 authorizes the President to provide assistance to NGOs involved in mediation and reconciliation efforts in Africa, using funds allocated for sub-Saharan Africa. The President is required to develop a long-term plan to support conflict resolution and demobilization activities in sub-Saharan Africa. The plan must detail the assistance to conflict resolution units and demobilization of military personnel in the region, including the countries receiving assistance and the reasons for their selection. The President must develop a plan for supporting conflict resolution and demobilization in sub-Saharan Africa, including assistance to NGOs, training programs, interagency coordination, and international cooperation. A report on the plan is due within 120 days. The President must submit a report to congressional committees within 120 days, detailing the plan developed for supporting conflict resolution and demobilization in sub-Saharan Africa. The President is required to submit a report to congressional committees every year on the progress of implementing the Act. Prior consultation with congressional committees is necessary before providing assistance under specific sections. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The House of Representatives passed the Act on September 19, 1994.
